Posts.Content: nbills511 wrote: Hi, I was wondering if anyone else noticed that they bruise much more easily in the months after chemo?  I am 6 months post chemo right now and I continuously find big, ugly bruises on my body with no recollection of how they got there.  I wasn't sure if that was typical...or if I should be concerned. Thank you! Nicole Dx 6/18/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bruise more easily after Chemo? nbills511 reesie

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 09:41AM nbills511 wrote: Hi in_cognito,  Thank you for the kind words.  I received my results this morning and they are unfortunately not good.  Invasive mammary carcinoma....which doesn't mean a whole lot to me at this point because I didn't really comprehend 95% of what my doctor was telling me.  I have an appointment later today to better understand what is going on, and what my next steps are.  Need less to say....I am still very much in shock :(
Posts.Title: Nervous and waiting... nbills511 luviris

Posts.Content: nbills511 wrote: First and foremost, I want to thank everyone for all of the information they are willing to share on this forum.  I have to say that your stories and support is very encouraging to read. I just turned 32 years old and have no family history of breast cancer to my knowledge.  Over the last couple of months, I have progressively developed an indentation/dimpling of my breast directly below my nipple when I raised my arm.  At first I didn't think anything of it, but as it progressed I become a little nervous.  My fiance and I did some research on the internet, and as many of your have stated, all the information that returned was rather alarming.  We both thought we felt something abnormal where the indentation was, so I scheduled an appointment with my ob/gyn.  He was very concerned by the disfiguration of my breast, and definitely felt something.  I was scheduled for a mammogram and ultrasound this past Wednesday (6/16).  After the mammogram and 2 ultrasounds, the radiologist informed me that there was definitely an abnormality that was picked up and that she unfortunately could rule out that it was a cyst.  She scheduled me for a biopsy that afternoon where they took several samples of tissue.  I am told I could potentially get my results back tomorrow, worst case scenario on Monday.  I am trying to stay calm but am having a very hard time not thinking the worst at this point.  If they can rule out that it is not a cyst, am I to assume that it is definitely a tumor (either malignant or benign)?  If it does turn out to be benign....would the tumor still need to be removed?  I know the odds are against it actually being cancer, but the fear and anticipation is starting to feel surreal... Dx 6/18/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Nervous and waiting... nbills511 luviris

Posts.Content: nbills511 wrote: I know there are quite a few threads out there on hair growth, so I apologize in advance for starting another.  I finished chemo 6 months ago (had my 6 month check-up today...yay!!) and my hair is coming in pretty nicely.  I am struggling with managing all of my new curls.  You can check them out at www.chiagal.com if you want :)  I don't have the heart to cut my hair yet (eek!), so I was curious what others have done to keep their curls in check?  How long did it take for your curls to finally grow out or has your hair maintained the curl?  Did you have to cut the curl off or did you hair eventually go back to it's original texture naturally? Thank you for the advice!  Dx 6/18/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo Curl nbills511 elmcity69

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 09:15AM - edited May 13, 2011 09:15AM by nbills511 @mamaof3bugs - your hair looks great!!  I am definitely going to try your perm suggestion. @yellowdoglady - that's so encouraging to hear that your hair has grown past your shoulders in 2 years.  I had very long hair before chemo....and it can be so discouraging sometimes because I feel like I'm never going to get there again :( I've never heard of issues with shedding...I'm glad you mentioned that though because I'm sure I would have freaked out when that happens to me and not expecting it.  I wasn't brave enough to shave my head once I started chemo so I watched my hair fall out chunk by chunk.  Any shedding of hair will probably cause a lot of anxiety at first!! Did everyone's hair grow evenly?  My hair is growing much quicker on the sides and back...and pretty slow on top...I'm going to have a mullet if I keep going at this pace!!
Posts.Title: Chemo Curl nbills511 elmcity69
